conclusion: A radial conductor of length r that rotates at a constant angular speed ω in a uniform magnetic field B (field perpendicular to the plane) develops an induced emf ε = ½ B ω r².
The circuit resistance is just R, so the current is I = ε / R = (½ B ω r²) / R.
That current in the moving rod experiences a magnetic force whose tangential component produces a resisting torque τ = ½ I B r² = ¼ (B² ω r⁴) / R.
To keep the rod rotating uniformly, the external agent must supply a torque of the same magnitude, so the mechanical power it delivers is P = τ ω = ¼ (B² ω² r⁴) / R.
Therefore, the power that the external force must supply is P = (B² r⁴ ω²) / (4 R).
